Questions.Question: According to the lesson, what does Sam's BorrowBookUseCase coordinate?
Options: HTTP request handling and JSON serialization
User validation, book availability, loan creation, and notifications
Questions.Explanation: The BorrowBookUseCase orchestrates multiple operations: checking user borrowing limits, verifying book availability, creating a loan, and sending notifications - all while staying independent of HTTP.

Questions.Question: According to the lesson, use cases should know about HTTP status codes and return them directly to handlers.
Questions.Explanation: Use cases should return domain errors. HTTP adapters translate these domain errors to appropriate HTTP status codes. Use cases are independent of delivery mechanisms.

Questions.Question: According to the lesson, which of the following are benefits of Sam's thin HTTP handlers after implementing use cases? Select ALL that apply.
Options: Handlers only translate HTTP to use case calls
Business logic can be tested without HTTP
Adding a CLI or GraphQL interface reuses the same use cases
Handlers contain all validation and business rules
Questions.Explanation: With use cases, handlers become thin translators. Business logic is testable in isolation, and new interfaces (CLI, GraphQL) simply call the same use cases. Business rules are NOT in handlers.

Questions.Question: According to the lesson, each use case represents a single _______ operation that the application supports.
Questions.Explanation: Use cases are 'single business operations as first-class citizens.' BorrowBook, ReturnBook, SearchBooks are each one complete business operation.
